titleInfo.title: Development of PCR-Lateral Flow Assays for the Onsite Authentication of Atlantic White Shrimp and Red Snapper

name.namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences

mods:mods.abstract: The Atlantic white shrimp and red snapper are of great economic value to the United States and have implicated for species substitution which is a violation of Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act Section 403: Misbranding of food. This impacts food safety and economical activities in the seafood industry in the US. Current methods for authentication are expensive, time, and labor intensive, hence not desirable for wholesale and retail applications. We designed and validated a species-specific PCR-lateral flow assay utilizing a miniaturized and cost-effective PCR instrument with 68 shrimp, prawn and fish samples from 14 seafood species. L. setiferus was simultaneously amplified by the multiplex assay to give three visual bands, which distinguished it from other species having either one or two bands on the dipstick. To improve upon the specificity of the red snapper assay, we developed and validated a rhPCR lateral flow assay where the thermotolerant RNase H2 enzyme was included in the PCR reaction to activate the red snapper-specific rhPCR primer. Amplicons generated in the duplex rhPCR reaction were detected using dual target lateral flow strips. The standardized assay was validated with 108 barcoded fish samples from 16 finfish species. Samples identified as Lutjanus campechanus or L. purpureus by DNA barcoding formed three distinct bands, while other fish species formed only two bands on the lateral flow strips. A minimum of 0.05 ng crude DNA was needed to obtain a visible band on the lateral flow dip stick. Both assays showed 100% specificity and took 90â€“120 minutes for completion. Our results confirm the ability of PCR and rhPCR-lateral flow assays as an important, economical, reliable, and alternative tool for species authentication in the seafood industry to mitigate food fraud. The assay generated results that can be used to authenticate Atlantic white shrimp and red snapper at various levels of seafood processing and commerce.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Cytochrome Oxisase 1, Lateral Flow, PCR, rhPCR, RNase H2 enzyme, Seafood
Prashant Singh, Professor Directing Thesis; Leqi Cui, Committee Member; Ravinder Nagpal, Committee Member.
